title: Gloucester struggles for answers as search for sunken fishing boat continues
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Authorities are in the next phase of investigating the Lily Jean's sinking, which left seven crew members presumed dead.
Search teams, including the Massachusetts Environmental Police, are using sonar to locate the sunken vessel off Gloucester's coast.
Gov. Maura Healey extended condolences and emphasized community support for the lost crew's families amid ongoing investigation efforts.

title: A new hotel has been approved in Boston’s Seaport
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Boston Zoning Commission approved a new 15-story hotel on Anchor Street in Seaport on February 11.
The project, by DGH Hotel Partners, will feature 438 rooms, a rooftop space, and a landscaped plaza.
The hotel is the final phase in a campus that includes Aloft and Element hotels, totaling 968 rooms.

title: $22m Beacon Hill townhome sale sets Boston’s single-family home sale record
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: A Beacon Hill townhome sold for $22 million, setting Boston's record for the most expensive single-family home.
The property at 46 Chestnut St., built in 1825, underwent a multi-year renovation by Dalfior Development.
Crest City Capital bought the home for $8.9 million in 2023 and restored its historic exterior details.

title: Dave Epstein on the possibilities of more snow Friday, a coastal storm Sunday-Monday
author: David Epstein
bullets: Massachusetts may see 2 to 4 inches of snow on Friday morning as a minor storm moves in.
A potential coastal storm Sunday night into Monday might bring snow, with likelihood varying across models.
Astronomically high tides early next week may cause minor coastal flooding and beach erosion.

title: Why a Virginia mom is running the 2026 Boston Marathon: ‘Stories can save lives’
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Elizabeth Ayres, 45, from Henrico, Virginia, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon to honor her late mother.
Ayres uses her participation to support the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention and raise mental health awareness.
Running provided Ayres strength and purpose after her mother's suicide, transforming her journey from grief to hope.

title: Report: Bill Russell’s widow sues his daughter over breach of contract
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Jeannine Russell is suing Bill Russell's daughter, Karen Russell, over comments made about his health in a Boston Globe column.
The lawsuit claims Karen's comments violated a previous non-disparagement agreement from a 2015 legal dispute over Bill's mental competency.
Bill Russell, Celtics legend who died in 2022, was honored with NBA-wide jersey retirement and the Finals MVP award named after him.

title: Pavel Zacha’s Olympic dream turned into a nightmare due to ill-timed injury
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Pavel Zacha was unable to attend the Milano-Cortina Winter Olympics due to an upper-body injury.
Zacha sustained the injury on January 29, during a game against the Philadelphia Flyers, impacting his Olympic plans.
Boston Bruins' coach Marco Sturm expressed disappointment for Zacha, who missed a key opportunity to represent Czechia.

title: Trump admin responds to lawsuit from Healey aide over work authorization
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Valentina Amaro Bowser sues Trump administration, claiming visa policies threaten her job as Healey's media director.
Federal government cites national security and lack of court jurisdiction in response to Bowser's lawsuit.
Bowser, a Venezuelan immigrant, faces visa hold despite pending permanent residency application after marrying a U.S. citizen.

title: Review & setlist: Nine Inch Nails get cinematic at TD Garden
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Nine Inch Nails performed a 21-song set at TD Garden on Feb. 13, with deep cuts and a cinematic stage show.
The band's set featured remixes, collaborations with Boys Noize, and marked drummer Josh Freese's first Boston appearance after joining.
The evening closed with fan favorites 'The Hand That Feeds,' 'Head Like A Hole,' and a cover of Johnny Cash's 'Hurt.'

title: Southie roommates built a massive igloo that went viral on social media. Then the vandals showed up.
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Southie roommates spent over 100 hours building an 8.5-foot igloo, gaining 40 million social media views.
Two men allegedly destroyed the massive igloo with a sledgehammer, as witnessed by a neighbor.
Photographer Jack Tarca expressed sadness over the vandalism, vowing to focus on positive content creation.
